bibl.title: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Philip Showalter Hench, February 18, 1956

div1.p: Tate's evidence was instrumental in getting Lambert's bill passed through the House.

div1.head: Letter from Paul L. Tate to Philip Showalter Hench, February 18, 1956
div1.opener:
Thormall
3-8192
1530 Tyler Street
Berkeley, California
February 18, 1956
Phulip S. Hench, M.D.
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
I neglected to acknowledge receipt of the Alumni Bulliten
of Jefferson Medical College, and program, honoring Doctor
Finlay.

I enjoyed reading it: even the letters of the old alumni
were of interest, so thank you for remembering me.

I wish I could have heard or read all the speeches made
regarding yellow fever and Finlay, especially yours.

While I am writing, wish to correct a mistake. I wrote
you that Lambert's bill passed the House January 25th.
But on February 7th I received a wire from O'Hara that
the bill had passed the House unamiously that day. Said
my evidence was greatly instrumental to passage.

I surely appreciate any of this reading matter you send
me and hope to hear from you again.
